abstract.text: Care for patients during COVID-19 poses challenges that require the protection of staff with 8 recommendations that health care workers wear at minimum, an N95 mask or equivalent while 9 performing an aerosol-generating procedure with a face shield. The United States faces shortages 10 of personal protective equipment, and surgeons who use loupes and headlights have difficulty 11 using these in conjunction with face shields. Most arthroplasty surgeons use surgical helmet 12 systems, but in the current pandemic, many hospitals have delayed elective arthroplasty surgeries 13 and the helmet systems are going unused. As a result, the authors have begun retrofitting these 14 arthroplasty helmets to serve as personal protective equipment (PPE). The purpose of this paper 15 is to outline the conception, design, donning technique, and safety testing of these arthroplasty 16 helmets being re-purposed as PPE. 17 18

It is recommended to wear a standard surgical mask 92 under the helmet system throughout the procedure. When gowning, it is important to create as 93 snug a fit as tolerated around the neck as this helps create the positive pressure. The tubing 94 should be pulled out of the gown to ensure that unobstructed room air is brought into the filtering 95 system (Figure 13) . These modifications will allow the user to have protection equivalent to or 96 potentially greater than the protection offered by an N95 mask and face shield, as confirmed by 97 particle flow testing. The design team has engaged with healthcare workers in anesthesiology, surgery, and respiratory 119 therapy to get feedback on the proposed design. Their collective thoughts are positive. They have 120 expressed that the design is comfortable, and they are relieved that additional PPE are available.

With the shortage of PPAR and the knowledge that this design is off-label this device has been 122 used by some anesthesiology staff and surgeons at our institution. We have consulted with PPE 123 at Duke's Biocontainment Laboratory to understand how PAPRs are tested and serviced at Duke, 124 and subsequently appropriate quality control check has been performed on each unit prior to use. 125 We have had technical conversations with engineers at Stryker who work on both the hood and 126 the helmet.

FIGREF0.text: patients during COVID-19 poses challenges that require the protection and safety of 20 staff. High risk of exposure to healthcare workers occurs with direct contact with respiratory 21 droplets. Formal recommendations have been issued by the Anesthesia Patient Safety Foundation 22 (APSF) recommending that health care workers wear at minimum, an N95 mask or equivalent 23 while performing an aerosol-generating procedure with a face shield. A powered air-purifying 24 respirator (PAPR) provides superior protection and may be warranted in patients with known or 25 suspected COVID-19. PAPRs pull air through a HEPA filter (N95 grade or better) into a suit to 26 create positive pressure with air always flowing out so that the person in the suit only receives 27 filtered air, thus minimizing exposure to the person in the suit. Risk of aerosolization is greatest 28 during intubation. In addition, specific surgeries and procedures that involve the 29 nasopharynx/oropharynx may carry similar risk to surgeons and other staff in the operating 30 room. Amid this, the United States faces shortages of personal protective equipment (PPE) [1]. 31 In addition, surgeons who use loupes and headlights have difficulty using these in conjunction 32 with face shields. Most hospitals have a limited number of dedicated PAPR units posing a 33 significant constraint when caring for multiple patients with suspected/confirmed COVID-19.

FIGREF1.text: Most arthroplasty surgeons use surgical helmet systems in efforts to decrease the patient's risk of 35 surgical infection and to protect surgical staff from infectious blood splashes/debris; with some 36 studies questioning the capacity surgical helmet systems to decrease contamination or deep 37 infection [2-4]. In the current pandemic, many hospitals have delayed elective arthroplasty 38 surgeries and the helmet systems are going unused.

FIGREF2.text: of need for PPE and helmets not being used led the authors to initiate an effort to 41 retrofit the Stryker Flyte helmets (Stryker, Mahwah, NJ) at our institution. This helmet system 42 (Figure 1) covers the entire head and neck. The system is designed to pull air in through the top 43 of the hood through a white section of AAMI Class 3 material. The air then passes through the 44 blue AAMI Class 4 material on the sides of the hood. A fan mounted in the top of the helmet 45 drives this flow. While Class 4 material provides the highest level of protection against 46 pathogens [5], the Class 3 material may allow some pathogens to pass through. Helmet systems 47 were used in conjunction with goggles and N95 masks during the 2003 SARS outbreak as using the helmet systems alone did not filter enough particles (0.02-1μm diameter) to meet the standard 49 for PAPRs [6]. While this system is not intended as a respirator, a novel solution has been 50 proposed with adaptation of the standard helmet system given the shortage of PAPRs and 51 potential shortage of N95 masks. The concept developed at our institution was to use a 3D 52 printing approach to create an adaptor for the Flyte helmet to allow conversion to a protective 53 PPE.

FIGREF4.text: 58helmets represented a possible solution to PPE shortage for high risk scenarios(Figure 2).59    Helmet modification, assembly, and quality testing was performed in collaboration with the60 Duke University Pratt School of Engineering. At the core of this modification is a single new 61 component, the manifold. The manifold sits over the (previously open) intake fan and creates a 62 sealed air path directly to the two mounted filters. The manifold is created from a Duke design 63 that is then 3D printed (additive manufacturing) to arrive at the final component. We used 64 Formlabs printers and their 'Durable' material for this new part. The engineering team worked to 65quickly design a robust manifold by using 3D printing(Figure 3). The first single-port design 66 was created on 3/22/2020(Figure 4). The single-port design had insufficient flow and choking at 67 the fan but proved the concept, so we went to a two-port design on 3/24/2020 (Figure 5). After 68 some user testing in the hospital we realized we needed to angle the ports down to better 69 accommodate the hood and the design was updated on 3/26/2020 (Figure 6). Then we optimized 70 the flow path and sealing area on 3/28/2020(Figure 7). Next, we moved the ports outwards to 71 allow for the rectangular Pall BB50T filter which provided enhanced performance on 4

FIGREF5.text: 77 helmet, creating a seal. The helmet is attached to the manifold and secured with zip ties that loop 78 through the eyelets in the front and back of the manifold (Figure 10). Two PALL BB50T 79 breathing circuit filters [7] are attached to the manifold. These are additionally secured with 80 rubber bands. Anesthesia tubing is attached with a standard Hudson multi-adapter (Figure 11). 81 82 Donning Technique for Helmet and Cover after Placement of Adapter 83 To prepare the hood, a seal is created against the white Class 3 material on top of the hood with 84 3M Tegaderm ™. If needed, this can be done in with sterile technique if a surgeon plans to wear 85 the helmet system. It is important to create the seal on the inside of the hood which can be 86confirmed by locating the exposed seam side(Figure 12). Two 8x12 inch 3M Tegaderm ™ strips 87 or multiple 4x10 inch strips can be used for this. The strips must cover the seams and overlap 88 with each other to ensure an adequate seal. In addition, this is done on the inside as a safety 89 measure so that positive air flow inside the hood pushes the strips up against the Class 3 material.

FIGREF7.text: Testing of Materials and Components.100    Testing was performed to monitor CO2 accumulation inside the hood using a GE Datex-Ohmeda101 Anesthesia machine for 30 minutes (no significant accumulation noted). Independent consultants 102 from Precision Air (Morrisville, NC) that certify clean rooms, HEPA filters, and PPE at Duke 103 University were engaged to perform particle flow testing. There are no patient-related risks 104 identified. In consideration of circumstances under which the device should not be used, users 105 should be knowledgeable in how to use/don/doff the surgical hood.

FIGREF8.text: CoV-2 is a novel virus that can be spread through respiratory droplets. We created a novel 109 design that modifies a Stryker Flyte helmet to filter intake air into the helmet to reduce the110 likelihood of SARS-CoV-2 transmission to healthcare providers. This product is especially 111 useful for health care providers involved in airway management or higher risk 112 surgeries/procedures in COVID-19 suspected or positive patients. We recognize that these 113 modifications constitute off-label use of the device and the introduction of new elements/features. Given the emergent circumstances of the COVID-19 pandemic and shortage 115 of PAPR devices, we propose that the risk of using this device are small in comparison to the 116 risk of COVID-19 transmission. We encourage physicians and other healthcare workers to weigh 117 these risks prior to use of the device.
